nodes.text: K-nearest neighbors (KNN) can be used to predict heart disease accurately from clinical and demographic features

The study implements a KNN-based predictive model using clinical and demographic attributes (age, sex, chest pain type, resting blood pressure, cholesterol, fasting blood sugar, restecg, max heart rate, exercise-induced angina, oldpeak, slope, ca, thal) to predict heart disease
Data preprocessing steps include feature selection, handling imbalanced data via weighting strategies, scaling and repeated trials (repeats = 3) with K set to 10 and averaging results
Model evaluation uses cross-validation, confusion matrix metrics (TP, TN, FP, FN), sensitivity, specificity, accuracy, and AUC-ROC to assess performance
KNN prediction relies on Euclidean distance to find K nearest neighbors and majority voting for class assignment; choice of K affects bias-variance tradeoff
The dataset includes 303 individuals identified as having heart disease (target variable coded 1=no, 0=yes) with attribute distributions visualized by histograms and gender counts
Feature importance analysis was used to improve interpretability and identify key factors contributing to heart disease risk
The KNN implementation repeated experiments three times with K=10 and averaged the trials to obtain stable performance estimates
Confusion matrix computed from predictions yielded counts used to calculate accuracy as (TP+TN)/(TP+TN+FP+FN)
The KNN classifier achieved 83% accuracy on the evaluated dataset based on confusion matrix (38 TP, 45 TN, 10 FP, 7 FN used in calculation)
Gender differences observed: males had a higher count of diagnosed heart disease cases than females, associated with higher cholesterol and resting blood pressure
Observed high accuracy and AUC-ROC values and feature importance insights indicate KNN provides promising predictive performance and interpretability for heart disease risk
Visualization (histograms) helped understand numerical feature distributions and supported preprocessing decisions
Conclusion: KNN is a simple, adaptable, non-parametric approach that can aid risk assessment and early detection of heart disease when integrated with appropriate medical datasets

Limitation: KNN is computationally expensive at classification time, sensitive to choice of K, and requires careful preprocessing; results are dataset-dependent and medical diagnosis should involve clinicians
